title: Project Stakeholders
description: Learn to identify and categorize the people who impact or are impacted by your project.
objectives: Define who stakeholders are and why early identification is critical
Distinguish between stakeholder, customer, sponsor, and end user
Identify stakeholders across internal and external categories
Recognize the risks of missing key stakeholders during project initiation

screens.headline: Alex's Mistake: Three Angry Stakeholders

items.text: You designed a kitchen without consulting ME? This violates code 3.4.2. You'll have to redesign everything.
I'm funding this expansion, and you made layout decisions without my approval? Who's managing this project?
I'm the one working in this space daily, and NO ONE asked me about the workflow. The customer entrance is in the wrong place!

dialogue.text: I thought I identified all the stakeholders. I scheduled a kickoff with the construction team, Maya, and Carlos. But I missed three critical peopleâ€”and now we're facing redesign costs, angry investors, and operational problems.

screens.learningHook: Stakeholders aren't just the people DOING the work. They're anyone who AFFECTS or is AFFECTED BY the project. Missing stakeholders early leads to costly rework.

screens.title: Stakeholder Identification & Classification
screens.instructions: Carlos gives you a second chance: Identify ALL stakeholders and categorize them.
screens.context: Restaurant expansion project. Budget: $850K, Timeline: 6 months, Goal: Expand market presence and increase revenue by 40%.

parts.title: Stakeholder Identification
parts.instructions: Select EVERY person who is a stakeholder. A stakeholder is anyone who AFFECTS or is AFFECTED BY the project.

options.text: Carlos Mendez (GM) - Project sponsor, approves budget
Ava (Investor) - Funded expansion, expects ROI
Inspector Lee (Health Inspector) - Must approve permits
Maya Rodriguez (Lead Chef) - Will transfer to new location
Jamie (FOH Manager) - Will manage customer service at new location
Rashid (Supply Chain) - Establishes vendor relationships
Construction Team (Best Build Co.) - Contractor performing work
Local Residents - Affected by noise, traffic during construction
Alex's Friend (Software Engineer) - No connection to project
Random Customer at Original Location - Not affected by expansion
Alex's College Professor - No involvement in project
Competitor Restaurant Owner - Not affecting this project

parts.title: Stakeholder Categorization
parts.instructions: Match each stakeholder to the correct role definition.

roles.label: Sponsor
roles.description: Authorizes project, provides funding/resources, approves major changes

roles.label: Customer
roles.description: Receives and approves deliverable, defines success criteria

roles.label: End User
roles.description: Will actually USE the deliverable in daily operations

content.definition: A stakeholder is any individual, group, or organization that may AFFECT, be AFFECTED BY, or PERCEIVE itself to be affected by the project.
keyInsights: NOT just people doing the work
Includes those IMPACTED by the project
May be internal or external to the organization

content.insight: External stakeholders are often MISSED because they're not in your daily meetings. But they can have enormous influence (regulators can shut you down!).

roles.name: End User
roles.example: Jamie (FOH Manager working in the space)

content.note: One person can hold multiple roles. Carlos is sponsor AND may be a customer. Maya is team member AND end user.

consequences.cost: Loss of trust, future resistance (Ava's anger)
Deliverable doesn't meet real needs (Jamie's workflow issues)
Changes late in project cost 10x more than early changes

content.insight: Stakeholder identification should happen FIRST, during project initiation. Changes found late are exponentially more expensive.

techniques: Review project charter and business case
Ask: 'Who will be affected by this project?'
Ask: 'Who has influence over project decisions?'
Look at organizational structure (who reports to whom)
Check past similar projects for stakeholders missed
questions: Who is impacted by the change?

correct.text: Good job identifying all 8 stakeholders. Now we won't have any more surprise confrontations like with Inspector Lee and Ava.
Excellent! Understanding who is sponsor vs. customer vs. end user helps you engage each stakeholder appropriately.

screens.title: New Project: POS System Upgrade
screens.context: Alex is assigned to upgrade Savory & Co.'s point-of-sale system across 3 locations.

questions.question: Who are the stakeholders for the POS upgrade project?

options.text: POS Vendor (software provider)
Front-of-house staff (will use the new system daily)
Elena (CFO - approves budget)
Customers (checkout experience affected)
IT Support team (will maintain system)
Restaurant across town (competitor)

questions.question: Front-of-house staff will use the POS system every day. What stakeholder role are they?

options.text: Sponsor
Customer
End User
Team Member

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've learned that stakeholders include anyone who affects or is affected by the project. Missing stakeholders early leads to costly rework.
takeaways: Stakeholder = anyone who AFFECTS or is AFFECTED BY the project
Internal stakeholders: team, sponsor, employees within organization
External stakeholders: customers, regulators, investors, community
Key roles: Sponsor (authorizes), Customer (receives), End User (uses daily), Team Member (does work)
Identify stakeholders EARLY during initiation to avoid costly surprises
Ask: Who approves? Who funds? Who uses? Who's impacted? Who could block?

artifacts.title: Internal vs External Stakeholders
artifacts.description: Visual diagram with Savory & Co. examples

characterClosing.text: I learned my lesson too. 'Just focus on the construction team' missed critical people like Inspector Lee and Ava. Now I understand: everyone affected IS a stakeholder.
